UnitType.Backstory:
Quendar legends tell of those that are unharmed by even the hottest fires. These individuals, if they exist, are said to be sacred. Rumors spread that Asha was one of these. The candles and campfires that she was tested against failed to harm her. Until the day Magnar came to her small village. He was irritated or threatened by the rumors and required a more demanding test, that she be thrown into a volcano to test her gift.
Though Asha tried to escape, her family dragged her to the volcanos edge and, as Magnar watched, they threw her in. While they expected her to rise uninjured from the lava, she was burned alive. Her screams echoed across the mountain and Magnar had her family thrown in with her for their lies. Three days later Asha rose from the lava, still burning, and walked back to her village. They immediately fell before her.

Many women who hate men have a reason for it, abusive fathers, cruel husbands or lecherous older men that used them. But you hate them for their weakness, their shallow understanding of motivation, their blindness to manipulation and deception.
Your third husband taught you your final lesson in dealing with men. Up until then you had pretended, schemed and deceived, important skills honed over the first two marriages. But for the third you stopped pretending and began running his estate yourself. Each time he complained you cut off a small part of his flesh.
That was when you became a queen. You already knew you could coax men into battle, but now you can command them. Before they would give you anything, now they give you everything.

Your mother is Queen Procipinee, an archmage, and each time she channeled the power of the shards that magic ran through you as well. Before you could breathe air you felt magic. Before you ate or drank you dreamed of adumbral worlds and listened to the song of the shards.
You refuse to be a timid princess, you march with soldiers and review war plans even though many scoff that the battlefield is no place for you. But they do not understand the power that you hold as natural as your beating heart. You do not command the shards as other channelers do, you are their child, and the power of Elemental is your birthright.

In the beginning they mockingly called you a queen. They laughed at your claims that you would survive through the raids and banditry that are common between Umber tribes, and that you would provide for those that followed you. But you persevered, your scouts kept you ahead of the raids, and you never allowed a betrayal to go unpunished. They say the Gandru's salty taste comes from the blood of those you've drown in the lake's brackish water.
Your real gift comes from scouring the areas that have already been picked over by others. You discovered the Tear of Kir-Tion in the Scoriac Ruins. Though you couldn't defeat the Teliost clan in battle you found their food reserves while they were raiding your camp. Without them they turned quickly on each other, a few days later they were submerged in the Gandru.

Back when Markin was only a guild leader and Umber was little more than scattered tribes, you fought in the Ruvenna arenas. You were their monster, and they brought you out to finish the gladiators close to claiming their freedom, much to the feigned shock and jeers of the crowd.
General Tarth was the last competitor you faced in the arena, and the first to truly challenge you. You fought in the blood-soaked sand until he looked up exhausted and asked, "Why do we fight each other when we hate them more?"
You both turned on your captors, and you cut through arena guards and fans alike. They hunted you for months, but you fled to the east and when you came across a small wraith village they worshipped you as a god. A title you gladly accepted.

The jungles south of Lake Zabril are a world apart from Anthys. All of the horrors mentioned in the book of Moriah are true, but you walked unafraid through the jungles depths. When the venomous ator bit you, it shriveled and died. When the drothanda hunted it avoided your camp, and when the infected river made the drinkers eyes bleed and body rot you were unaffected as everyone around you died.
You were briefly the queen of a dead city, both cursed and blessed, until Enil Markin's trade ships sailed into the cities port. Agreeing to leave the city behind you helped him load his ships and followed him to Tan-ta-Kreet. As you sailed away you saw Zad-Zabril for the last time as night closed on the ruined city, and the drothanda moved in from the jungle to claim the bodies.

In the years following the cataclysm, when the west was little more than roving barbarian hordes and the east was. much worse, Walderon, the Duke of Ruvenna and last of the great merchant-lords marshalled the forces of his city and kept civilization from being extinguished.
You are descended from his line. Procipinee and her dainty daughter may claim magical inheritance, Markin's vast iron stores make him formidable, but the third age would be ruled by Darkling Shamans, Trog barbarians and Quendar half-men if it wasn't for your people.
Even now they forget the rules of civilization and launch short sided wars with each other for blood soaked fields which they hold just long enough to die upon.

You father was the chief of a great library. You grew up surrounded by stacks of musty tomes and old legends. While other children's bedtime stories were haunted with creatures like Rabisu and Cnotta, you heard the legends of Lord Avalan and his circlet. You dreamed of the marble palaces of Malaya and the red-haired queen Breon of the Nimmerians.
It was this last dream that lingered most on your mind. Breon was an inspiration, a strong queen who led a kingdom, but there was more. A feeling that you were tied to this ancient queen, that you are destined to live, or die, as she had.

You were once a revolutionary, marching beside Carrodus to overthrow the corrupt Council of Lords. You were a warrior and general, a husband and father. You freed men from tyranny, until the day you were ordered to enslave the rebels south of the Gandru.
You have done worse. You murdered the children of Council members to secure Carrodus's claim, you took from farmers to feed your soldiers, you were a tyrant. But this was too much. You freed the rebels and refused Carrodus command, and for that he enslaved you instead.
You fought for seven years in Capitar's arena before leading a second uprising. Now you lead the revolution and you have the opportunity to make up for past mistakes.

Though Verga was formidable, he was not unstoppable. Capitar warriors cut him down, though it took nearly eight of them to do so, and half did not survive the battle. For days Verga swam in that grey area between life and death, his blood mixed with the earth of the battlefield, and he battled with the ghosts of warlords long dead.
But even death lost its battle with Verga and under an eclipsed moon he awoke and dragged himself forward. He is no longer the man he once was, death shadows him and whatever slight mirth he may have once held has been left at that broken battlefield.
